titlestmt.titleproper: Christensen, C. Roland (Carl Roland), 1919-1999. C. Roland Christensen Papers, 1931-1998: A Finding Aid

titlepage.titleproper: Christensen, C. Roland (Carl Roland), 1919-1999. C. Roland Christensen Papers, 1931-1998: A Finding Aid
titlepage.author: Baker Library
titlepage.p: © 2009 President and Fellows of Harvard College

did.abstract: Research, teaching materials, writings, speeches, administrative records, audio recordings and other papers of Harvard Business School professor C. Roland Christensen.

processinfo.p: By: Jeffery Mifflin; revised Dominique Tremblay, April 2008; revised Laura Williams, May 2009.

Digital content on physical media has been extracted when possible. Files were surveyed, screened for privacy and confidentiality concerns, and transferred to secure storage. Content open for research is described at the series and folder levels below.

accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.
Researchers must register and provide valid photo identification before using this collection.
Materials stored offsite. Please contact histcollref@hbs.edu for more information.
Restricted material has been identified and separated. Note that box and folder lists of restricted material have been redacted.
Digital use copies in this collection can be accessed only onsite in the de Gaspé Beaubien Reading Room. To request access please contact histcollref@hbs.edu prior to visiting the library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: C. Roland Christensen Papers. HBS Archives. Baker Library. Harvard Business School.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections:
relatedmaterial.p: Christensen’s HBS doctoral dissertation, “Management Succession in Small and Growing Enterprises,” 1953 is filed with the HBS Archives Thesis Collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note:
bioghist.p: Carl Roland Christensen was born in Tyler, Minnesota, in 1919, the son of teachers. He received his Bachelor of Arts degree from the University of Iowa in 1941 and a Master of Business Administration and Doctor of Commercial Science degree from Harvard Business School in 1943 and 1953, respectively. During and immediately following World War II he served as a Captain in the U.S. Army Quartermaster Corps, 1943-1946.

Christensen became a Research Assistant in Business Administration at Harvard Business School in 1946 and an Instructor in Business Administration in 1947. He was promoted to Assistant Professor (1948) and Associate Professor (1954), becoming a full Professor of Business Administration in 1958, and the George F. Baker, Jr. Professor of Business Administration in 1963. Appointed as the Robert Walmsey University Professor by Harvard president Derek Bok in 1984, Christensen was the first Harvard Business School faculty member to become a University Professor. In fact, Christensen played a major role in the development of the Derek Bok Center, established in 1975 to heighten the quality of undergraduate instruction at Harvard. Within the Harvard community, Christensen taught at the Harvard Law School, the Harvard Medical School, the Graduate School of Education and the School of Public Health. His teaching activities outside of the Harvard community included teaching at IMEDE, an international school of management in Laussane, Switzerland, the Stanford Graduate School of Business, and the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Business Policy, case method instruction and developing discussion leadership skills were Christensen's major areas of teaching, study and research throughout his career. In addition, as the director of many businesses, Christensen observed various problems associated with the decision-making process and the effective functioning of boards of directors. His research interests included investigations into ways of improving the operation of such boards.

Christensen is widely recognized as one of the leading experts on the art of teaching by discussion and on the effective use of the case method and field studies in education. His teaching methods were designed to promote the active involvement of students, encouraging them to express, share, and compare ideas by using classroom techniques that are sensitive to the needs of individual students without surrendering control of the instructional process. The case method at HBS confronts students with problems encountered by managers and uses the problems as a basis for exploring theoretical concepts as well as practical issues. At the request of Derek Bok in the mid 1970s, Christensen built on these concepts and developed two influential seminars designed to improve the quality of teaching: Developing Discussion Leadership Skills and Teaching By the Case Method. For over twenty years, Christensen organized and co-taught classes for university faculty members, both within and beyond the Harvard community, enabling them to hone their skills at leading discussions and molding their abilities to question, listen, and respond. In fact, although formally retired in 1990, Christensen was actively engaged in teaching seminars on discussion and case method teaching until shortly before his death.
Christensen passed away on August 28, 1999 in Nashville, Tennessee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note:
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of annotated cases, teaching notes and other course materials, case development files, correspondence, speeches, administrative records, audio recordings, writings and drafts of publications related to teaching. The annotated cases and supporting course materials such as course outlines, reading lists, memoranda, seating charts, rosters and transcripts of presentations, illustrate Christensen's approach to teaching as well as his questioning, discussion and course management techniques. Specific HBS courses represented are Field Studies (1964-1984), Administrative Policy (1947-1953) and Business Policy (1951-1979). Christensen's case development activities are illustrated through the Nike, Inc. Case Development Files, which include handwritten notes and questions as well as a transcript of an interview with Nike co-founder Philip Knight. The records relating to the Colloquium on Teaching by the Case Method held in 1984 provide a number of perspectives expressed by various speakers concerning the case method and its effectiveness.

Materials relating to Christensen's efforts to improve the teaching skills of university professors by Developing Discussion Leadership Skills and Teaching By the Case Method courses include annotated cases developed by Christensen, Dr. Abby J. Hansen and others specifically for these courses. Other teaching and seminar planning materials include topical notes, discussion questions, correspondence, teaching plans, memoranda, agendas, schedules, programs and catalogs of seminar participants. Also included are topical notes, personal reflections, periodical clippings, cartoons and quotations assembled by Christensen that provide insight into his personal teaching philosophy. Other records include materials related to Christensen's books Teaching and the Case Method and Education for Judgment: The Artistry of Discussion Leadership, publications not authored by Christensen and other materials. Also included are digital drafts of Teaching and the Case Method and other draft material on teaching and class discussion used in Christensen's books and seminars.

Research materials include a group of articles maintained by Christensen as "Article Files." Speeches made by Christensen between 1963 and 1996 elucidate Christensen's thoughts on the nature of teaching and on various methods of instruction.

Christensen's administrative activities are represented by correspondence, handwritten notes, memos, guidelines, course outlines, reports, exams, course evaluations and other materials related to Administrative Policy and Business Policy courses. Christensen's MBA Review Committee records (a committee assembled with the purpose of creating a strategic plan for the MBA program at HBS), include memos, reports, notes and related documents from 1959-1961.

Audiovisual records include an audio recording and transcription of a 1997 interview between Christensen and Albert Bartovics and Carole Foster about the development of Business Policy cases and their use in HBS courses. Also included are audio recordings of Christensen speaking at the Cotting Library in 1982, a 1988 interview with Bob Eccles, and a video recording entitled Case Video to Accompany Business Policy Text and Cases, which contains video segments of a number of instructors, including Christensen, to accompany Business Policy: Text and Cases, 7th Ed, a book that Christensen co-authored.

arrangement.head: Series Outline
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in the following series:

list.item:
Series II. HBS Teaching Records, 1931-1998
Subseries A. Annotated Cases, circa 1948-1990
Subseries B. Business Policy Teaching Files, 1948-1990
Subseries C. Case Development Files, Nike, Inc., 1983-1984
Subseries D. Colloquium on Teaching by the Case Method, 1984-1988
Subseries E. Field Studies, 1964-1984
Subseries F. Teaching Materials and Course Development, 1947-1996
Subseries G. Teaching About Teaching, 1931-1998
i. Annotated Cases Used for Teaching About Teaching, circa 1940-1998
ii. Reflections, 1975-1997
iii. Seminar Teaching Materials, circa 1950s-1997
iv. General, 1931-1998

Series III. Research, Writings and Speeches, 1946-1996
Subseries A. Writings and Speeches, 1960-1996
Subseries B. Article Files, 1946-1974

Series IV. HBS Administrative Files, 1946-1970
Subseries A. Administrative and Academic Planning Files, 1946-1970
Subseries B. MBA Review Committee Files, 1959-1961

scopecontent.p: The series consists of Christensen’s correspondence with Ernest Arbuckle, Dean of Stanford Business School, and supporting materials, regarding approaches to business school curricula.

did.unittitle: Arbuckle, Ernest (Dean of Stanford Business School), 1959-1980

scopecontent.p: This series consists primarily of printed cases with associated notes and annotations as well as other teaching notes and supporting materials. Also included are Nike case development files, materials on the 1984 Colloquium on Teaching by the Case Method, Field Studies course material, records related to Christensen's seminars on discussion and case method teaching, as well as topical notes and reflections related to teaching. This series also contains digital content of Teaching and the Case Method and of work relating to teaching and class discussion.

Case teaching files, including annotated cases, handwritten notes, questions, and supporting materials used by Christensen to teach classes at HBS are represented. Many materials relate to the teaching of Business Policy courses. The files in Subseries A are similar those in Subseries B, Business Policy Teaching Files, 1948-1990, which Christensen separately maintained as "Business Policy Teaching Files." Cases in Subseries A seem to have been more actively used by Christensen, while the cases in Subseries B seem to have been used more regularly as a reference resource for selecting or comparing cases. Cases developed for the teaching of Developing Discussion Leadership Skills and Teaching By the Case Method seminars can be found in Subseries G, Subgroup I, Annotated Cases Used for Teaching About Teaching, circa 1940-1998.

Subseries B. Business Policy Teaching Files, 1948-1990

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of cases annotated by Christensen in preparation for their use in the classroom at HBS. Many case files contain supplementary teaching notes and supporting materials in addition to the printed or mimeographed cases themselves. Subseries B materials are similar to Subseries A, Annotated Cases, circa 1948-1990, but were maintained separately by Christensen. Therefore, they have been kept as a separate subseries within the collection.

Subseries C. Case Development Files, Nike, Inc., 1983-1984

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of folders created by Christensen while developing teaching cases concerning Nike in 1984. Materials include handwritten notes and questions, as well as a transcript of his 1983 interview with Nike's co-founder Philip Knight.

did.unittitle: Transcript Interview, Philip Knight, from tape made at Nike, Inc., 1983
Subseries D. Colloquium on Teaching by the Case Method, 1984-1988

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of files relating to the HBS Colloquium on Teaching by the Case Method held in 1984 in honor of the school's seventy-fifth anniversary. Materials include schedules, background readings and speeches. Of special interest is a speech by HBS student Robin Hacke, describing from a student perspective how the case method affects business education.

did.unittitle: Speeches: Hacke, Robin, “The Case Method, a Student Perspective,” 1984

scopecontent.p: This subseries reflects the activities of HBS students conducting field studies at business locations throughout the United States. Files include instructions for interviewing in the field, notes on observation techniques, course materials for Field Studies and Business Policy classes, and sample readings.

did.unittitle: Field Studies in Business Policy, A Suggested Basic Library in Management, January 1981

Field Studies in Business Policy, overview, n.d.
“How a Field Study Is Done,” n.d.
Subseries F. Teaching Materials and Course Development, 1947-1996

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of material related to teaching and course development, and includes course outlines, reading lists, handwritten notes, transcripts of presentations, memoranda, seating charts and rosters from HBS courses. Among the courses represented are Administrative Policy (1947-1953), Business Policy (1951-1979), Developing Discussion Leadership Skills (1978-1983), and Faculty Teaching Seminars (1982-1986). Developing Discussion Leadership Skills and Faculty Teaching Seminars were designed to sharpen the classroom skills of instructors who employ discussion teaching or the case method.

processinfo.p: Subseries F consists of folders identified during processing and grouped together as a convenience to researchers. It also incorporates materials related to Business and Adminstrative Policy courses added to the collection in 2007.

arrangement.p: Course-specific materials are followed by general materials arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.p: The materials in this subseries consist primarily of teaching materials related to seminars, workshops, colloquia and other courses taught by Christensen. Main seminar topics are Developing Discussion Leadership Skills and Teaching by the Case Method. Included are annotated cases, topical notes, correspondence, permission requests and agreements, teaching plans, questions, notes, agendas, memoranda, quotations, newspaper and other periodical clippings, seminar schedules and programs, and catalogs of seminar participants. Also present are files containing Christensen's thoughts and reflections on teaching, including handwritten notes, clippings and cartoons. This subseries also contains digital content of Teaching and the Case Method and of work relating to teaching and class discussion. This subseries consists of four subgroups.

acqinfo.p: These records were added to the collection in 2007.

did.unittitle: i. Annotated Cases Used for Teaching About Teaching, circa 1940-1998

scopecontent.p: This subgroup consists primarily of cases developed by Christensen, Dr. Abby J. Hansen and others for use in Developing Discussion Leadership Skills and Teaching by the Case Method seminars. Teaching notes and supplementary materials are included.

scopecontent.p: The records included in this subgroup consist of Christensen's personal notes, topical notes, reflections on teaching and on life in general, as well as articles, periodical clippings, cartoons, and quotations culled by Christensen. They provide interesting insight into his personal philosophy and thoughts on teaching.

This subgroup consists of seminar-specific teaching notes, readings, correspondence, seminar outlines, seminar planning and other materials from Christensen's seminars, including Developing Discussion Leadership Skills, Teaching by the Case Method, Teaching and the Case Method, and others.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of articles and speeches by Christensen as well as various publications not authored by Christensen that he separately maintained as "Article Files". This series also contains digital content of Christensen's Class if 1963 Reunion speech and articles written by Christensen relating to discussion-based teaching.

This subseries includes an article published by Christensen in 1960 and speeches made by him between 1963 and 1996. Many of the speeches are concerned with the nature of teaching and the possibilities of improving instruction by the case method. This subseries also contains digital content of Christensen's Class if 1963 Reunion speech.

scopecontent.p: The series is comprised of one restricted subseries: Administrative and Academic Planning Files; and one open subseries: MBA Review Committee Files. The Administrative and Academic Planning Files consist of materials formerly kept in looseleaf binders, arranged, for the most part, according to academic year. The bulk of the subseries concerns the teaching of Business Policy and planning for the administration of Business Policy courses between 1950 and 1970. Included are correspondence about programs, handwritten notes by Christensen, memos and guidelines, course outlines, reports, exams, course evaluations, and other materials. A smaller amount of similar files for Administrative Policy, 1946-1957, is also included. The MBA Review Committee Files consist of memos, reports, handwritten notes by Christensen, and related documents from 1959-1961. The main thrust of the Committee's work was to create a strategic plan for an improved future MBA program at HBS.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. Administrative and Academic Planning Files, 1946-1970

accessrestrict.p: Restricted until 2020. Folder titles have been redacted.

did.unittitle: Subseries B. MBA Review Committee Files, 1959-1961

scopecontent.p: The series consists of audio cassettes, CDs, and a transcription of Christensen being interviewed by Albert Bartovics and Carole Foster (of Baker Library, Historical Collections) about the development of Business Policy cases and their uses at HBS. The recordings were made at Christensen’s Lexington, Massachusetts, residence in September 1997. Additional recordings, including Christensen's talks at the Cotting Library in 1982, an interview with Bob Eccles in 1988 and a videorecording entitled "Case Video to Accompany Business Policy Text and Cases" featuring Christensen, are also included.

acqinfo.p: The additional audio recordings were added to the collection in 2007.
